headline.main: New York City Opera Announces Deal With Unions
headline.print_headline: City Opera Clears Hurdle In Union Negotiations

docs.abstract: The company cleared a major obstacle in its effort to forge ahead in reduced form and without its Lincoln Center home, saying on Wednesday that it had reached agreements with both of its major unions.
docs.snippet: The company cleared a major obstacle in its effort to forge ahead in reduced form and without its Lincoln Center home, saying on Wednesday that it had reached agreements with both of its major unions.

docs.lead_paragraph: New York City Opera cleared a major obstacle in its effort to forge ahead in reduced form and without its Lincoln Center home, saying on Wednesday that it had reached agreements with both of its major unions. Rehearsals were to begin immediately.

docs.abstract: Easier eligibility for some government programs for the needy has contributed to the rise in government spending, an economist writes.

headline.main: Ask the Elder Law Attorney: Disclosures and Loans

docs.abstract: Attorney Craig Reaves on financial disclosures to siblings and repayment of loans.
docs.snippet: Attorney Craig Reaves on financial disclosures to siblings and repayment of loans.

docs.lead_paragraph: Craig Reaves, past president of the National Academy of Elder Law Attorneys, practices elder law in Kansas City, Mo., and fields occasional questions from New Old Age readers. Submit yours to newoldage@nytimes.com. Please limit your queries to general legal issues, as Mr. Reaves cannot respond with individualized legal advice. Questions have been edited and condensed.

docs.lead_paragraph: Corrections appearing in print on January 18, 2012.
docs.snippet: Corrections appearing in print on January 18, 2012.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Your Money column on Jan. 7, about financial strategies for those laid off shortly before retirement, referred incompletely to the possibility of taking money out of a company plan, like a 401(k), to pay health insurance premiums. While such a transfer is technically possible, the rules governing it are more onerous than those that apply to withdrawals from an I.R.A.
